title: Power - new power when emf is doubled

content.question: A resistor is connected to a battery of <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> <math alttext="uppercase script E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math> in a closed circuit, and the total power dissipated in the resistor is <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi></math>. The battery is then replaced by a second battery having <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> <math alttext="2 uppercase script E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>. When the resistor is connected to the second battery, is the power dissipated equal to <math alttext="2 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>P</mi></math> or greater than <math alttext="2 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>P</mi></math>? What reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: Equal to <math alttext="2 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>P</mi></math>. The power dissipated is proportional to the potential difference, which doubles.
Equal to <math alttext="2 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>P</mi></math>. The power dissipated is proportional to current, which doubles.

Greater than <math alttext="2 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>P</mi></math>. The power dissipated increases exponentially with current and potential difference, both of which double.
Greater than <math alttext="2 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>P</mi></math>. The power dissipated is proportional to current times potential difference, both of which double.

content.answer: Greater than <math alttext="2 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>P</mi></math>. The power dissipated is proportional to current times potential difference, both of which double.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
